column1: ACL reconstruction is surgery to reconstruct the ligament in the center of your knee.
A tear of this ligament can cause your knee to give way during physical activity.
Other kinds of anesthesia, like regional anesthesia or a block, may also be used for this surgery.
Your surgeon will use the camera to check the ligaments and other tissues of your knee.
Your surgeon will fix any other damage found, and then will replace your ACL by following these steps: - The torn ligament will be removed with a shaver or other instruments.
- Your surgeon will attach the new ligament to the bone with screws or other devices to hold it in place.
At the end of the surgery, your surgeon will close your cuts with sutures (stitches) and cover the area with a dressing.

ACL reconstruction may be used for these knee problems: - Knee that gives way or feels unstable during daily activities - Knee pain - Inability to continue playing sports or other activities - When other ligaments are also injured - When your meniscus is torn Before surgery, talk to your health care provider about the time and effort you will need to recover.

The risks from any anesthesia are: - Allergic reactions to medicines - Breathing problems The risks from any surgery are: - Bleeding - Infection Other risks from this surgery may include: - Blood clot in the leg - Failure of the ligament to heal - Failure of the surgery to relieve symptoms - Injury to a nearby blood vessel - Pain in the knee - Stiffness of the knee or lost range of motion - Weakness of the knee
